awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photomechanical Behavior in Photovoltaic Semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Photovoltaic semiconductors are capable of converting light into electricity. They are the principal components of solar cells that provide renewable energy from sunlight. These semiconductors tend to fail in a brittle manner, limiting their general use to small-scale applications. New evidence shows though that the mechanical behavior of photovoltaic semiconductors is sensitive to sunlight, exhibiting the potential of relative malleability under illumination. The mechanisms underlying such light-mechanical coupling effect remains elusive. This award supports fundamental research to elucidate how light-induced excitation controls the mechanical behavior of photovoltaic semiconductors. The new knowledge is expected to offer strategies to design highly stable and durable photovoltaic devices, such as solar cells, transistors, light-emitting diodes, and photodetectors, providing the basis for extensive engineering applications. This award will also offer education and training for graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary areas of mechanics, materials science and engineering, and photophysics. The award will promote diversity by involving women and underrepresented minorities in research activities.

The photomechanical behavior of photovoltaic semiconductors is determined by light-induced deformation mechanisms such as dislocation and twinning. In this project, a multiscale modeling and experimental framework will be used to accurately characterize the influence of photoinduced electron-hole excitation on the dislocation and twining mechanics in cadmium telluride, a prototype photovoltaic semiconductor. On the sub-atomic scale, advanced quantum mechanics simulations will be performed to determine the influence of electron-hole pair on the energy and force barriers of dislocation and twin nucleation, as well as dislocation mobility. On the atomic scale, the carrier concentration dependent mechanisms of the dislocation-dislocation and dislocation-twin interactions will be characterized using reactive force field based molecular dynamics simulations. On the mesoscale, the light-illumination effect on the stress-strain behavior will be quantified by developing an atomically-informed crystal plasticity model that incorporates dislocation slip and deformation twinning. Theoretical predictions will be validated through mechanical testing and materials characterizations using advanced experimental techniques, including nanoindentation, scanning probe microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and electron backscatter diffraction. This work will result in a  new physical picture of the deformation mechanism of photovoltaic semiconductors under light illumination, and provide a comprehensive understanding of light-mechanical coupling effects in general photovoltaic materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes Section

In this project, we developed a multiscale approach that couples density functional theory, constrained density functional theory, machine learning force fields, and atomistic modeling to illustrate the impact of light illumination on the mechanical properties of cadmium telluride (CdTe). CdTe is a promising II-VI semiconductor with excellent electronic and mechanical properties used in solar cells and other optical applications.

Through our research, we first identified the deformation mechanisms of single-crystal CdTe, which involve dislocation nucleation and phase transitions depending on the deformation along different crystallographic orientations. We then examined the dislocation core structures and their stability in CdTe, establishing the most stable dislocation core structure in the absence of light. Next, we investigated how light-induced electron-hole pairs affect the energy barrier for the glide of dislocation cores. We found that these electron-hole pairs (generated under light-illumination) decrease the energy barrier for the 30º Te-core dislocation—most likely to be activated compared to other cores—due to its attraction to holes, while the effects on the 30º Cd-core dislocation are not significant. Molecular dynamics simulations using machine learning force fields suggest that the hardening effect arises from increased Peierls stress and reduced strain concentration at the dislocation core at low light intensity. As light intensity increases, the softening effect is present due to the changes in the mobility of various types of dislocation cores. With the support of this award, we have published five papers in leading scientific journals such as Nature Materials and the International Journal of Plasticity, and we have one manuscript in preparation.

Tuning the mechanical properties and defect structures of semiconductors using external stimuli (e.g., light) can extend their engineering applications to various environments and manufacturing processes. The theoretical framework established in this project provides a fundamental basis for future theoretical studies on photoplasticity and electroplasticity of various types of semiconductors, including covalent, ionic, and organic semiconductors.

The research outcomes from this project have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses through homework assignments and class projects. We have trained the next generation of scientists, engineers, and skilled technical workers in the field of mechanics of materials and structures. In particular, several minority students and postdoctoral researchers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines have participated in this research project and have been well-prepared for their future academic and industrial careers. With the support of this award, one female graduate student has obtained her Ph.D. degree from Iowa State University and is continuing her postdoctoral research at Caltech. In addition, two postdoctoral scholars were supported by this award.
